TypeSignature.Value: public class Timer : System.Web.UI.Control, System.Web.UI.IPostBackEventHandler, System.Web.UI.IScriptControl
.class public auto ansi beforefieldinit Timer extends System.Web.UI.Control implements class System.Web.UI.IPostBackEventHandler, class System.Web.UI.IScriptControl
Public Class Timer Inherits Control Implements IPostBackEventHandler, IScriptControl
public ref class Timer : System::Web::UI::Control, System::Web::UI::IPostBackEventHandler, System::Web::UI::IScriptControl
type Timer = class inherit Control interface IPostBackEventHandler interface IScriptControl

Docs.summary: Performs asynchronous or synchronous Web page postbacks at a defined interval.

remarks.format: ## Remarks In this topic: - [Introduction](#introduction) - [Declarative Syntax](#declarative_syntax) ## Introduction The control enables you to perform postbacks at a specified interval. When you use the control as a trigger for an control, the control is updated by using an asynchronous, partial-page update. You must include a object in a Web page to use the control. You use the control to update an control by including the timer inside the control. Alternatively, you can place the timer outside the control and set the timer as a trigger. You can also initiate full postback of a complete Web page by including the control in the Web page and not setting it as a trigger for an control. You can run server code when the timer interval has elapsed by creating an event handler for the event. In the event handler, you can include code that dynamically adjusts the behavior of the control. Set the property to specify how often postbacks will occur. Set the property to turn the on or off. > [!NOTE] > The accuracy of when the control posts back to the Web server depends on the accuracy of the ECMAScript (JavaScript) `window.setTimeout` function that is running in the browser. The property is defined in milliseconds. You must set the property to a value that lets at least one asynchronous postback complete before the next postback is initiated. When the control is outside an control, the timer continues to run while the content of the control is refreshed. If a new postback is initiated while an earlier postback is being processed, the first postback will be canceled. The default value is 60,000 milliseconds (60 seconds). > [!NOTE] > Adding a control with a small value in the property can generate significant traffic to and from the Web server. Use the control to refresh the content only as often as necessary. ## Declarative Syntax ``` ``` ## Examples The following example shows an control that displays a randomly generated stock price and the time that the stock price was generated. The control updates the content in the control every 10 seconds. > [!NOTE] > In this example, the timer interval is set to 10 seconds so that when you run the example, you do not have to wait a long time to see the results. Because each timer interval causes a postback that causes network traffic, in a production application you should set the interval to the longest time that is still practical for your application. [!code-aspx-csharp[System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Atlas/System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer/cs/Default.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Atlas/System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer/vb/Default.aspx#1)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the control initiates a postback to the server after the number of milliseconds specified in the property has elapsed.
Docs.value: if will initiate a postback; otherwise, . The default value is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Enabled%2A> property to turn the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> control on and off. When you set <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Enabled%2A> to `true`, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> control starts its timer countdown when the Web page is rendered.
On postback, you can change property values in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Enabled%2A> property, and the changes will be reflected when the Web page content is rendered in the browser. If you change the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Enabled%2A> property and then change it back to its original value during the same postback, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> control runs as if no change had been made.
## Examples The following example shows an <xref:System.Web.UI.UpdatePanel> control that displays a randomly generated stock price and the time that the stock price was generated. By default, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> control updates the content in the <xref:System.Web.UI.UpdatePanel> control every 10 seconds. The user can decide to update the stock price every 10 seconds, every 60 seconds, or not at all. When the user decides not to update the stock price, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Enabled%2A> property is set to `false`.
[!code-aspx-csharp[System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer.Interval#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Atlas/System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer.Interval/cs/Default.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer.Interval#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Atlas/System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer.Interval/vb/Default.aspx#1)]

Docs.summary: Retrieves properties from a object that are passed to the client component that implements timer logic in the browser.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.GetScriptDescriptors%2A> method adds the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Interval%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Enabled%2A> properties from an instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> class to a <xref:System.Web.UI.ScriptDescriptor> object. The client component accesses the values and sets the corresponding values in script.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the number of milliseconds to wait before initiating a postback.
Docs.value: The number of milliseconds to wait before initiating a postback. The default value is 60,000 (60 seconds).

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Interval%2A> property to set how often the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> control initiates a postback to the server. You can change the value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Interval%2A> property in server code after a postback, such as in an event handler for the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Tick> event. The accuracy of when the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> control posts back to the Web server depends on the accuracy of the ECMAScript (JavaScript) `window.setTimeout` function that runs in the browser.
> [!NOTE] > Setting the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Interval%2A> property to a small value can generate significant traffic to and from the Web server. Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> control to refresh the content only as often as necessary.
When you change the value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Interval%2A> property, the ECMAScript timing code running in the browser will be reset when the updates are rendered.
## Examples The following example shows an <xref:System.Web.UI.UpdatePanel> control that displays a randomly generated stock price and the time that the stock price was generated. By default, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> control updates the content in the <xref:System.Web.UI.UpdatePanel> control every 10 seconds. The user can decide to update the stock price every 10 seconds, every 60 seconds, or not at all. The <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Interval%2A> property is set to the user's choice.
[!code-aspx-csharp[System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer.Interval#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Atlas/System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer.Interval/cs/Default.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer.Interval#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Atlas/System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer.Interval/vb/Default.aspx#1)]

Docs.exception: The specified value is less than or equal to zero.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Tick> event is raised when the number of milliseconds specified in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Interval%2A> property has elapsed either since the Web page was rendered or since the previous <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Tick> event.
## Examples The following example shows an <xref:System.Web.UI.UpdatePanel> control that displays a randomly generated stock price and the time that the stock price was generated. The <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> control updates the content in the <xref:System.Web.UI.UpdatePanel> control every 10 seconds. The stock price and the time are set in a handler for the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Tick> event.
[!code-aspx-csharp[System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Atlas/System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer/cs/Default.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Atlas/System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer/vb/Default.aspx#1)]

remarks.format:
## Remarks This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> instance is cast to an <xref:System.Web.UI.IScriptControl> interface.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.GetScriptDescriptors%2A> method adds the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Interval%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Enabled%2A> properties from an instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> class to a <xref:System.Web.UI.ScriptDescriptor> object. The client component retrieves the values and sets the corresponding values in script.

member this.Tick : EventHandler<EventArgs>

Docs.summary: Occurs when the number of milliseconds specified in the property has elapsed and the page is posted to the server.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Tick> event is raised when the number of milliseconds specified in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Interval%2A> property has elapsed either since the Web page was last rendered or since the previous <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Tick> event. Handle the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Tick> event when you have to perform actions during each postback.
## Examples The following example shows an <xref:System.Web.UI.UpdatePanel> control that displays a randomly generated stock price and the time that the stock price was generated. The <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> control updates the content in the <xref:System.Web.UI.UpdatePanel> control every 10 seconds. The stock price and the time are set in a handler for the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Tick> event.
[!code-aspx-csharp[System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Atlas/System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer/cs/Default.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Atlas/System.Web.UI.Controls.Timer/vb/Default.aspx#1)]

member this.Visible : bool with get, set

Docs.summary: Overrides the property of the class to prevent this value from being set.
Docs.value: if the control is rendered on the page; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The `Visible` property is overridden in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> class to prevent setting this property. The `Visible` property returns `true` if the client component of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> class is included in the Web page, even if <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Enabled%2A> is set to `false`. The `Visible` property returns `false` when it is inside a container, such as an <xref:System.Web.UI.UpdatePanel> control, whose `Visible` property is set to `false`.

Docs.exception: A value is assigned to the Visible property.
